required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Can Blood Flow Restriction Therapy Improve Strength for Shoulder External Rotators Better Than Exercise Alone
clinical_study.official_title: Can Blood Flow Restriction Therapy Improve Strength for Shoulder External Rotators Better Than Exercise Alone

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the ability of blood flow restriction therapy to improve strength of shoulder muscles during the sidelying external rotation (ER) exercise versus a control group who only performs the sidelying ER exercise.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine if blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy is superior at increasing strength of the shoulder (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, posterior deltoid, and middle deltoid) and increasing tendon size of the supraspinatus and infraspinatus (as determined by diagnostic ultrasound) while performing the sidelying external rotation exercise compared to those who only perform the sideyling external rotation exercise without BFR.
Subjects will be randomized to one of two treatment groups: exercise with BFR or exercise alone. Recruitment will be a sample of convenience consisting of healthy adults (age range 22 to 45). Subjects will perform the sidelying external rotation exercise 2 times a week for an 8 week period.

study_design_info.masking_description: Outcomes assessors are blinded to group allocation.

primary_outcome.measure: Muscular Strength as Measured by Dynamometry
primary_outcome.description: Use a hand held dynamometer (MicroFet 2) to measure strength of the middle and posterior deltoid, the supraspinatus, and the infraspinatus

primary_outcome.measure: Tendon Size as Measured by Diagnostic Ultrasound
primary_outcome.description: Ultrasound images are capture at pre- and post-test sessions

arm_group.description: Subjects will perform the sidelying external rotation exercise 2x a week for 8 weeks. The BFR cuff will be applied to the upper arm. Arterial occlusion will be set to 50%. Subjects will perform 4 sets (30, 15, 15, 15 reps) with a 30 sec rest period between reps. The occlusion will be maintained for the 8 min treatment period.

Subjects will perform the sidelying external rotation exercise 2x a week for 8 weeks. This group will not have BFR applied. Subjects will perform 4 sets (30, 15, 15, 15 reps) with a 30 sec rest period between reps.

intervention.description: Subjects will perform sidelying external rotation exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Healthy adult (age 18 and older) with no current shoulder pathology
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Current neck, shoulder (or general upper extremity), and/or thoracic spine pathology
2. Shoulder surgery (or general upper extremity surgery) during the prior 6-month time period
3. Cervical/thoracic spine surgery during the prior 1 year
4. Subject having one or more contraindications for BFR training.

facility.name: George Fox University School of Physical Therapy

clinical_study.keyword: infraspinatus, external rotators, blood flow restriction
